content:
Continuing discussion from #general->tshirt design competition:

It would be fun to have pin badges for pycon, with various levels of python/open-source/zulip branding. How do these work? From @Alicja Raszkowska's picture I'm imagining there is a 1'' pin in the back, a printed on cardstock(?), and then maybe two-sided tape sticking the to the pin?

Another idea could be to use larger pins (2.25''?), print circular stickers, and then stick the stickers to the pins.

I usually decoupage them
- print on regular paper using a laser printer
- glue it to a plastic sheet with decoupage glue (transparent plastic file folders work great)
- paste wide transparent scotch tape on top of the print
- cut everything out
- use decoupage glue or varnish around the cutout
- attach a pin on the back (I have just the pin parts, without the round part)
some old designs
back front
I make earrings in a similar fashion - print the design 4 times (2 regular and 2 mirrored), use the plastic in the middle, attach earring hooks (we call them beagles)
old designs
some are being made this week :)
we could also make fridge magnets easily, just paste a sticker on a magnetic sheet and cut it out
I could experiment with the process a bit and simplify, e.g. your idea for the two-sided tape would make it easier than decoupage glue :)
the shape doesn't matter that much, but I'd advise it should be reasonable - too much detail makes it tedious and it wouldn't be fun to cut them
wow, these are amazing!
I guess we should decide if we intend these mainly for "Zulip people", in which case we can make them in luxury (of time), or if we intend these to be given out / made at the booth

as far as the cost goes:
- one plastic file folder is enough for about ~40-60 pins or half as many pairs of earrings
- I've been using the same decoupage glue bottle and tape for the past ~3years
- earring hooks are about $0.10 a pair and pins are probably also around that (prices in Poland shouldn't be much different)
- scissors are easy to come by
- my tools for attaching hooks to earrings were about $5 a piece, we'd need at least one of each (going to grab them to take pics :))
thank you :) I really love making them
IMG_4074.JPG

oh, and we'd also need thin, soft wire to attach the hooks and a safety pin to make holes in the earrings :)
(changed from bobby pin - that probably wouldn't work )

while in NYC I've been able to get all the tools and supplies pretty easily, took me 1 trip to a crafts shop, so they're easy to come by - ordering online from Amazon would probably make the process really simple :)
You should be able to find stuff like this in Portland. :)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UBPT1pgByqc

Cost is probably not a big factor, given how much everything else costs. More just if someone is coming to our booth, we probably only have a few minutes to make them anything we make.

Python or octopus earrings could be cool!
magnets are by far the easiest and fastest thing to make - we could encourage people to cut them out themselves
with pins it would take some encouragement, but it's not much more work, we just need to attach the pin part

earrings are tricky, I think we could definitely make them for Zulip folks, but one pair means cutting the same design 6 times (4 for the printed design and 2 for the plastic part), unless we make mirrored stickers, then it's only twice the work as compared to pins :)
I could do a proof of concept octopus design for earrings and if we have any other ideas, I could also make pins/earrings from them & take pics
I'm in the middle of an earrings batch anyway, so it's not much work for me :)
@Steve Howell I definitely thought of that at least a few times, but I get tired after making ~20 earrings every few months :)
